# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

```julia
function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    # Filtering on manufacturer and model
    df_audi = df_cars[df_cars.manufacturer .== "audi", :]
    df_a4 = df_audi[df_audi.model .== "a4" || df_audi.model .== "a4 quattro", :]

    # Creating a new column with `true` across all rows
    for row in eachrow(df_a4)
        row[:audi_a4_type] = true
    end

    return df_a4
end
```

This function first filters the original DataFrame `df_cars` to only include rows where the manufacturer is "audi". Then it filters this subset further to include only those models that are either "a4" or "a4 quattro". Finally, it iterates over each row of the filtered dataset and sets the new column `audi_a4_type` to `true` for all rows. The function returns the resulting DataFrame with the added column.
